channel.topic:
Introducing: NOVA ⚡️a global, decentralized engine for drug discovery
now live on #bittensor subnet 68! 

NOVA pushes virtual drug screening beyond state-of-the-art models and transforms it into a high‑speed race for breakthroughs that rewards experts and enthusiasts alike for identifying synthesizable compounds with the highest affinity for key drug targets from a billion size database. 

our subnet functions as a back to back hackathon, running 24/7. miners are encouraged to continuously develop and refine ai models and heuristic approaches that make drug hunting in a vast chemical universe more efficient.


🔗 gitHub: https://github.com/metanova-labs/nova
🔗 website: https://www.metanova-labs.com/ 

earn rewards for finding the best molecule the fastest, scoring submissions, or staking $TAO.

interested? you too can help shape the future of medicine

About SAVI and the combinatorial libraries expansions

SAVI already covers a billion‑scale, one‑step chemical space. Because every virtual hit is generated by varying a single reagent, most hits will be surrounded by hundreds to thousands of likely accessible neighbours obtained by changing just one reagent. The reaction rules in SAVI were selected to cover the most relevant bond or ring forming reactions in medicinal chemistry at the time, so the molecules sampled cover a high number of “drug‑like” molecules that also have a high chance of successful synthesis. SAVI is like a fast, low‑risk path from virtual screening to synthesis, representing a substantial starting point in terms of hits and analogues identification, prioritization and synthesis. Billion-sized chemical databases are known to be substantially better than million-sized databases in virtual screening performance and hit rate when performing the biological assays (given the adequate hit-picking strategies are employed during the prioritization process).

Larger libraries with many, well‑vetted (and in some cases sequential) reaction templates multiply both chemical accessible diversity and analogue depth. Each additional reaction opens an independent path for molecular variation, allowing very large reagent combinations to be expressed while retaining practical, catalogue‑based synthesis routes. The result is that every prospective hit sits in a denser analogue neighbourhood of “make‑ready variants”. Furthermore, by choosing strategic reaction types, the subsequent libraries can be biased toward scaffold classes that single‑step reactions can under‑represent, increasing the novelty character of the compounds and range of phys-chem properties of the compounds.

Running SAVI and the broader multi‑reaction libraries in parallel for the same target prior to chemical synthesis captures the strengths of each. For example: SAVI could be the source of molecules that could be ordered and tested first with the multi‑reaction space screened simultaneously, so once a SAVI hit shows activity we already have a data‑ranked list of “deeper analogues” for ordering (in cases of two-step reactions expanding on SAVI scaffolds). In other cases, molecules coming directly from the multi-reaction libraries could be prioritized instead of SAVI molecules if the molecules picked for synthesis from SAVI do not present enough analogues or have other undesired properties that are present in the series as a whole. This is very target dependent. 

This dual approach can reduce downtime between hit confirmation and analogue expansion and increase chemical novelty, while keeping every potentially promising series based on synthesis routes that are proven and catalogue‑friendly.

In short, these expansions are key for flexibility and scalability of the platform in the long run, but that does not mean SAVI compounds are not very useful in the drug design process.

It is about the numbers game of maximizing the success rates when going for the biological assays, meaning good scores and high diversity will provide more entry points to potentially successful new drugs. The more diversity with the right predictions the better, but this does not mean SAVI-based submissions are bad or not useful.

Hey Alister, you’re right that the workflow you outline of target focused pre‑processing, multi GPU inference on the filtered set with antitarget + entropy optimization, and a growing cache of bad binders has been a successful formula for the current incentive model. We’ve seen the quality it produces, and we also recognize the side effect: because miner spend naturally scales to whatever the incentive will reimburse, the contest slides from algorithmic creativity to a GPU arms race (while utilizing the strategies above and with the current structure) once everyone adopts that similar playbook.

This is why we want to rebalance. We are iterating on the incentive model (such as those suggusted in discussion) to capture maximum value from miner submissions while preparing for sustainability long term by leaning into smart, adaptive searching strategies that will outcompete pre computations at scale as we introduce more complexity (additional screening stages, larger models, expanded datasets, more dynamic parameters etc). The burn keeps emissions from funding excess hardware, and allow us to tune them with the task. We want the efficiency miners are capable of developing and harnessing is what will secure the subnet’s long‑term success for everyone.

1.  Burning just shrinks the pie;  it doesn’t sort miners by performance-per-cost or reward the efficient ones
2. You can’t see miners’ real costs or where “excess” starts, so with that information gap, a flat burn is just a blunt value transfer
3. More complexity can still devolve into a hardware arms race, it just moves the battlefield

It’s unclear why the owner wants to regulate miners’ internal implementations (algorithms, hardware spend). These dimensions are largely unobservable and non-verifiable; I’m not aware of any system that has successfully enforced them.

To remove ambiguity, let me normalize the numbers:

Scenario A (“smarter algorithm”): 10 miners, each running 10×4090, for a total of 100 GPUs.
Scenario B (“brute force”): 2 miners, each running 30×4090, for a total of 60 GPUs.

Both reach the same target/quality.
So how do you define “hardware waste”?

If you go by total GPU count, A “wastes” more.
If you go by decentralization/miner count, B is worse (more concentrated).
If you go by performance-per-compute (tokens/$/kWh, etc.), you first need a verifiable, observable metric—which you don’t currently have.

Bottom line: When compute/cost is unobservable, a flat burn can’t selectively punish “waste”; it just taxes everyone.

None of these are the key points.  The key point is that the owner feels they have given too much to the miner.  The owner believes that they are paying the miner a salary, with a budget of 1.76m$ for a year is much enough.  All the other reasons are justifications for budget cuts.

**Update Announcement: ** @nova・68 

Summary:
- We are introducing dynamic reaction based challenges. The epoch’s starting block hash will be used to select a single allowed reaction (or SAVI) with the same mechanism used for antitargets. 
- Submissions for a given epoch must come from that reaction's product set, 
- This keeps the challenge dynamic, limits seach space per challenge, and allows us collect more data on underused reaction families.

How to prepare:
- You can find the implementation in the ``epoch-reaction-selection`` branch where the old get_challenge_proteins_from_blockhash function has been changed to get_challenge_params_from_blockhash, returning both proteins and allowed reactions. 
- Familiarize yourselves with combinatorial db and product generation rules in ``reactions.py``

When:
Update will go live at :Wednesday, August 6, 2025 10:00 AM,  ``3PM UTC``, epoch ``17067``.

**NOVA Incentive Mechanism Updates** @nova・68 

Over the past few months, we have engaged extensively with partners across the pharmaceutical industry and academia to refine the product–market fit for our approach to advancing drug design and virtual screening through #bittensor #SN68. Based on feedback from interested partners, market participants, miners, and direct input from @const_reborn, we will introduce two major updates to the mechanism.
Beyond technical improvements, this phased update is designed with broader ecosystem goals in mind:

- **Reduce barriers to entr**y by making miner objectives and operations more transparent, enabling wider participation.
- **Foster collaborative competition**, where anyone can contribute expertise for rewards, and open-source solutions allow miners to build on each other’s work—creating a virtuous cycle of innovation.
-** Equalize miner compute spend for validation**, improving efficiency and sustainability.
- **Respect partner sensitivities** by accommodating situations where certain data (e.g., therapeutic targets) must remain private.
- **Improve transparency in benchmarking**, with clear internal metrics and the ability to run continuous assessments rather than relying solely on periodic wet-lab validation.
- **Shift from hardware to software**, emphasizing algorithmic performance over raw compute power.
- **Enhance IP safety**, creating a more robust and trusted framework for traditional pharma players, allowing for partners to keep their data private or only share it under CDAs.

**Historical Evolution of the Subnet **

Since launching on March 1, NOVA has grown into a discovery engine generating synthesizable chemical libraries exceeding 7M molecules for targets including classic transporters like dopamine and serotonin and epigenetic modulators of the HDAC family in humans and rodents.
Together these upgrades have aligned the subnet more closely with how drug discovery is actually done: navigating a massive, noisy chemical universe while filtering for what matters. Each step was designed to address specific bottlenecks in virtual screening and move closer to real-world application.
- **Single target / single molecule prediction** was the starting point, but left gaps in the score function, particularly with false positives from PAINS compounds.
- **Antitargets **were introduced as a proxy for selectivity and chemical diversity (given the weekly target rotation), filtering out PAINS and improving the diversity of the chemical submissions for the target during the week.
- **Sets of molecules** per challenge increased throughput, allowing broader exploration of chemical space.
- **A Shannon entropy bonus **was added to reward molecular diversity, avoiding narrow or repetitive submissions.
-** Fine-tuned models with rotating weekly targets and random antitargets** further improved predictive quality and reduced overfitting.
- Target-specific blacklists increased unique molecule throughput while eliminating copy mining.
- Finally, **combinatorial databases **enabled deeper exploration of drug-like chemical spaces, highlighting the need for efficiency in searching beyond simple database enumeration and increasing the number of potential candidates from 1 to 45 billion molecules.

Through SN68 we generated chemical libraries of synthesizable compounds for multiple targets that align with our R&D interests, of special interest libraries focused on the dopamine transporter, serotonin transporter and norepinephrine transporter and for multiple histone deacetylases (for proteins from humans and rodents). We will continue to improve upon the data encompassed in these libraries, so they can be used as a basis for hit-picking and ultimately the development of new drugs.

**Phase I: Boltz-2 integration**

The first update will integrate Boltz-2 and PSICHIC for molecular screening- 2 complementary models.

**Boltz-2 **is a structure-based computational model that predicts how proteins and small molecules interact and quantifies their binding strength recently released by #MIT and #Recursion. By leveraging three-dimensional structural information and a “ligand + protein co-folding methodology”, it achieves physics-level accuracy (free-energy perturbation simulations) at a fraction of the computational cost of the physical calculations, enabling rapid virtual screening and supporting early lead optimization. This speed–accuracy balance substantially accelerates the path from hit identification to viable drug candidates.

**PSICHIC **is a graph-based model that derives protein–ligand interaction fingerprints directly from sequence and SMILES, embedding physicochemical principles to assess binding potential quickly and at scale. Capable of screening hundreds of thousands of compounds per hour, it is well suited for early triage in discovery pipelines. 

Deployed together, the two models provide a complementary, orthogonal screening strategy:** PSICHIC** offers fast, large-scale filtering of chemical space, while **Boltz-2 **delivers detailed structural and affinity predictions to validate and refine top candidates. This layered approach combines breadth with depth, creating a more efficient and rigorous foundation for virtual screening.

Given the additional computational requirements for running Boltz-2 in addition to PSICHIC we will be decreasing miner burn to 50%.

**Phase II – Focusing on Efficient Search**

Phase II shifts the subnet’s competition model away from raw compute races and toward **efficient search strategies**. This is in line with recent updates by @ridges_ai and @gradients By capping both compute and time budgets, participants will be incentivized to design smarter algorithms for finding high-scoring solutions with the models in the stack, rather than simply outspending one another on hardware. Importantly, miners will now **submit code for screenings**, and validators will** evaluate this code in a standardized manner in terms of hardware and time for code to run** across all miners, ensuring fairness, comparability, and reproducibility.

This change has several advantages:
- **Democratization of access**: miners with modest resources can compete effectively, lowering barriers to entry and broadening participation.
- **Better leverage of expertise**: emphasis shifts from GPU horsepower to algorithmic innovation, encouraging creative approaches to search and optimization.
- **Sustainability**: equalizing compute spend reduces waste and aligns incentives with efficient resource use - software competition >> hardware competition
- **Stronger pharma alignment**: the model accommodates sensitive partner data (e.g., targets) remaining private, while still enabling collaborative benefit from the subnet’s predictive power.
- **Transparency and reproducibility**: code submission combined with standardized validation and continuous benchmarking provides clearer improvement metrics, avoiding reliance solely on periodic wet-lab validation.

By realigning incentives in this way, Phase II enforces the original subnet subnet goal of being  software- and algorithm-driven competition, creating a fairer, more efficient, and more partner-compatible foundation for collaborative drug discovery, considering the key feedback points from miners and from the industry.

**Token Sales**

To fund updates and growth, we will begin selling 9 TAO/day worth of NOVA. In order to support token health and the long-term sustainability of the network we have minimized sell pressure. With liquidity now more consolidated, self-funding operations has become possible and is an important step to ensure the continued development and management of the subnet. 

**Next Steps**

Together, these steps position the network not only as a high-performing discovery engine but also as an open, sustainable, and secure platform for collaboration across pharma, academia, and the broader computational sciences community.
- **Phase I:** The Boltz-2 integration is in the final stages of testing and will be available for review next week. 
- **Phase II: **We have started design of the new incentive mechanism. While some of the more specific details are still under planning and development, we are looking forward to sharing a detailed plan with the community soon.

I’m curious about the code submission part, with the reactions based not being a search only problem, it’s not just a blank algorithm that starts from zero every time, it’s based on some very specific fingerprinting and data build out. It’s not compute heavy as I’m mining with just a 3090, but it took weeks to get to being competitive because of all the organizing, fingerprinting, initial layouts that are not going to be available to the validator… any thoughts?

Good point, the intent with Phase II isn’t to eliminate out the value of the data organizing and fingerprinting work miners have already done, but to shift it into a transparent and reproducible format.

Likely validators won’t load in large pre computed libraries, or the same curated data build outs. Instead, miners who can encode their heuristics (on the fly fingerprinting, filtering, diversity optimization strategies) into their submitted code will be rewarded. The key is making it portable so it runs under the a compute/time budget and can be generalized to different targets and datasets. 

That said, we’re still finalizing specifics like runtime/GPU limits, allowed resource constraints, and evaluation protocol, and we want to shape these together with miners to make sure existing strategies and new developments can be expressed effectively in the new format.

Yeah I think the key here is to establish a standardized validation sandbox so that miners know what they are working with. Probably will have to tailor things a bit to what tools and resources the standardized validation environment has, but I’m interested to see how many of each miner’s tools will translate.
Will this be another part of the score or is Nova moving completely over to this scoring mechanism.
Is Boltz-2 available ?
@urdof | nova [τ, ظ ]

Totally, it's important that the validation environment is standardized and that everyone knows its specs. If there are any specific tools besides the libraries we already use you think may be helpful, we can definitely investigate the feasibility of integrating it to the validation environment. 

I think how well strategies will translate to the new format is strongly tied to its reliance on enumerating the combinatorial DBs, especially as we add more reactions and it becomes less and less practical to do so. That being said, one possible way to make this transition is to adapt search strategies to be applied over the precursors instead of the final molecules.

For phase I, Boltz-2 and PSICHIC scores will be like different competition tiers, but for phase II we plan on completely moving towards the scoring mechanism urdof described. It would still be pretty helpful to run screening tasks like the one we have today, though. Depending on how much progress is made on the sub subnets project, we might even want to keep both formats going.

We are finalizing work on Boltz-2 integration to NOVA, we plan on releasing the new branch for review in the upcoming week, but I'll link some resources that can be helpful for you guys to prepare in the meantime:
Paper: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2025.06.14.659707v1
Original repo: https://github.com/jwohlwend/boltz
Thanks for sharing!
I’d say a combination of both would be interesting. Tapping into miners for their screening/inference tools can be beneficial.

The primary focus will shift to the algorithm development outlined in phase two, but we're also considering directing a variable portion of emissions to screening / inference that can benefit from the open source developments.

Hey all, gentle reminder:

If you're approaching Bittensor and/or Bittensor subnets as an investment, and you simply want to monitor the subnet channels to see what the project is doing to update and support mining and validation operations and development, that's fine.

But **subnet owners are not allowed to provide support for investors/traders in this server.** If your question boils down to "how are you going to provide me a return on my investment" or "how are you going to ensure that I, as a staker, make a profit", **this isn't the server for you.**

Please check the pinned posts in any subnet to see if the project provides support for investors/speculators/traders in their own private server, or check the dTAO Discord, which provides channels to those projects that don't have their own servers.  You can find an invite link to the dTAO Discord in the "Useful Links" article in the #❓・faq channel.

If your message is about price/market chat or speculation, or is investor-focused (seeking support for ROI/staker profit), it'll be deleted.  If you persist, you may be timed out or even banned.  So if your posts are being deleted, reflect on the fundamental question or issue you're talking about in the post.  If it's about support for you as a staker/investor, that's why. https://x.com/metanova_labs/status/1973387426942070839?s=46

Just to discuss, under the new mechanism, for example, if both miners have contributed to the algorithm, how can we evaluate which miner's algorithm is better? And how should we reward the miners? If other miners also copied the algorithm of the previous round's miner, then how should the rewards be distributed in the next round?

In my opinion, the new mechanism is unfavorable for the miners. It's somewhat like "obtaining the miners' innovative solutions in a short-term and low-cost incentive mechanism all at once". However, we believe that as a r&d company, the algorithm is precisely the most valuable.

Finding the optimal solution is far beyond the scope of a single search algorithm. Infrastructure, computing power, and algorithms are all crucial factors for success. Just submitting an algorithm is not enough; validators cannot verify it.

Hey @f86_mt, ty for bringing your points on our new mechanism. A lot to cover in terms of the changes to come, but a few key points on the sub-subnets-based system to come: 

SN68 will start running two sub-subnets, ph1 sub-subnet will encompass what we have today (decentralized screenings based on Boltz2 and PSICHIC fine-tuned models), while ph2 sub-subnet will be focused on algorithmic submissions. Ph1 sub-subnet will be a competition that still have algo, infrastructure,  and computing power and key variables for winning. In parallel, Ph2 sub-subnet will standardize the hardware used for validation, and will have the algorithms as the key variable to be rewarded. Code will be available with enough time for everyone to go through it, discuss it here and contribute prior to implementation, but the key metric will be how better are the algorithms submitted in terms of finding good compounds gives a fixed hardware and a fixed time to run. We will arrange rewards to what provides the subnet with the most value, but miner's can participate in either or both based on their skills. If you prefer to keep strategies private for a portion of the rewards this is still possible while also rewarding the miner with the best open sourced algorithm.

Prior to sn68 I worked with drug development innovation in multiple projects.  One key point brought to me when discussing sn68 with multiple past partners was the culture difference in terms of open-sourcing targets and molecules of interest - Traditional institutions (our potential clients and partners) in many cases want to keep the targets and chemical classes they are working on private. Even though we at Metanova see a strategic path for doing it openly by only keeping the biological validation information of hits and leads private prior to patenting, many more traditional institutions will take more time to adapt to a decentralized drug screening world. Because of that, the ridges algo competition model makes a lot of sense here, since it will allow us to get closer to match IP concerns of potential clients. 

We are open to discuss details of it and to build together, always focusing on bridging the value created here to the off-chain world in a way that brings value to the chain as a whole.

🚀 NOVA Blueprint - Phase II Code Release @nova・68 

We’re excited to share NOVA Blueprint, our new incentive mechanism and soon to be sub-subnet on Subnet 68.
This repo outlines the updated architecture and design for this next stage of NOVA’s expanding network.

🔗 Repo: https://github.com/metanova-labs/nova-blueprint

It’s open for review and discussion, we encourage miners and community members to check it out, test things, and share feedback or ideas.

Note: This isn’t the final version that will go live yet, we’re still updating it, adding features, and refining components.

If have something you want to see included (like dependencies, privileges, or other ideas), let us know, and we’ll be considering miner input as we finalize the Phase II release.

Looking forward to start this next phase with everyone and keep building NOVA together!🔧 💊

I have a few questions:
- how things will go if an algorithm heavily depends on pre-worked, pre-filtered dataset, which might be big.
- how to evaluate algorithm's score fairly: whether to evaluate them with the average score over several epochs or single highest score within the evaluation period

The second one would be particularly important for miners.
Because, with the "winner takes all" rewarding scheme, many miners are working with opportunistic algorithm, which would result in highest score on one epoch, but bad scores  on others, without focusing on average performance over the epochs.

Hey team!

Would be great to verify your subnet metrics on Tao Revenue to make sure we are displaying them correctly. Who can I speak to regarding this? 🙏

1 - The impact of pre-filtered datasets will be lower for nova blueprint because the target protein in addition to antitarget proteins is selected randomly before runtime to place an emphasis on generalizability. For this reason, depending how things go, we may disqualify or ban submissions that overly rely on pre-worked datasets
2 - For now, we're using highest score within the evaluation period, but considering allowing the previous winner to continue earning emissions if no other submissions can outperform them by a defined threshold in following epochs. This would require the code to perform consistently well on the various parameters to win multiple epochs.
